loans.name: Marciano

texts.es:
In October of last year, Marciano Lopez H. started a business selling clothing for children, men, and women, such as: t-shirts, pants, shorts, and button-down shirts. Marciano gets his merchandise in the municipal market. He and his brother-in-law then sell them door-to-door all over the city. His sales are done on credit with weekly payments. Each week Marciano goes out to sell and also to collect payments for the clothes he has sold on credit. The demand for his merchandise has been increasing due the easy payment terms he offers. For the winter season he wants to increase his stock of merchandise. For that reason he is requesting a loan of $500.00, which he hopes to be able to pay in 12 months.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Marciano Lopez H. empezó en octubre del año pasado un negocio de venta de ropas para niños, hombres y mujeres tales como: remeras, pantalones, bermudas y camisas. Don Marciano adquiere sus mercaderías en el mercado municipal de la ciudad; el realiza sus ventas a domicilio por lo que sale con su cuñado a venderlas casa por casa por toda la ciudad. Marciano realiza sus ventas a crédito con pagos semanales. Cada semana Don Marciano sale a vender y a cobrar los pagos de la ropa que ha vendido a crédito. Actualmente, la demanda de sus mercaderías a ido incrementandose gracias a la facilidad de pago que el ofrece. Para la temporada de invierno quiere aumentar su stock de mercaderías para ello solicita un crrédito de US$ 500 que espera poder pagar en doce meses.

loans.use: To buy an inventory of winter clothing

loans.name: Mirella

texts.es:
Business Description

Mirella has 10 years of experience as a seamstress. She worked with her mother, which is how she learned her trade. Two years ago she started her own business and with the help of some money her husband saved she was able to buy the raw materials she needed to open her business. Mirella specializes in school uniforms and flags. Her workshop is in her home and she works Monday through Saturday from 8:00am until 7:00pm.

Loan Use

Mirella will use the loan to purchase more raw materials, such as leather and fabric. There is much demand for her work right now, particularly for sports uniforms as many schools will be celebrating their schools’ Olympic games and have placed orders with Mirella. She would also like to use some of the loan money to purchase materials in order to make improvements on her home and workshop.

Personal Information

Mirella is 30 years old. She is married but has no children. Her husband is a security guard at a clinic and therefore also contributes toward household expenses. They live in a little house made of cane and wood given to them by her mother. They are working hard to be able to reconstruct the house, which is in a fairly unstable condition. Mirella hopes to grow her business and continue improving the quality of her life.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Kenney Molloy, Kiva volunteer

Descripción del Negocio

Mirella tiene 10 años de experiencia en esta actividad. Ella trabajaba con su mamá y fue así como aprendió este trabajo y hace 2 años ella se independizo y con un dinero que le dio su esposo empezó a comprar su propia materia prima. Mirella hace todo lo que es uniformes para las escuelas y porta estandarte de las banderas. Ella tiene su taller en su domicilio y trabaja de lunes a sábado desde las 8:00am hasta las 7:00pm.

Uso del Préstamo

Ella desea con el crédito comprar materia prima como cuero y telas ya que en este tiempo tiene bastante demanda de uniformes deportivos ya que muchas escuelas están celebrando las olimpiadas escolares y le han hecho pedidos de uniformes. Además que va a usar algo del crédito para compra materiales para mejorar su vivienda.

Información Personal

Mirella tiene 30 años y esta casada pero no tiene aun hijos, su esposo es guardia de seguridad en un clínica y percibe también un ingreso que le permite aportar para los gastos del hogar. Ellos tienen su casita de caña y madera que le dio su mamá y juntos están trabajando duro para poder construir su casa ya que las condiciones son muy precarias. Ella aspira crecer con su negocio y a su vez ir mejorando su calidad de vida.

loans.use: Purchase fabric to increase her production

loans.name: Betsy Carolina

texts.es:
Betsy always worked with her mother and ended up inheriting the business. She's single and has no children. She lives in her parents' house with her sisters who are students and help with the business that they have in the Hoyada marketplace. Through this business, Betsy is able to help cover education costs for her sisters. To fully take advantage of her time, she begins work very early and works from Monday to Sunday due to the demand for her products. She has a freezer at home and now the only thing that worries her is that she doesn't have her own stand in the marketplace to continue in her business endeavor. In order to obtain a spot and continue in her efforts, she is asking for a $700 loan. She can thus buy a spot in a better location. She is eternally grateful for your contribution.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Betsy trabajó con su mamá siempre, y es de ella que heredó el negocio, es soltera y no tiene ningún tipo de responsabilidad familiar propia, vive en la casa de sus padres en compañía de sus hermanas que estudian y colaboran con ella en el puesto que tienen en el mercado la Hoyada; de esta manera ella las apoya colaborando con los gastos que generan sus respectivos estudios. Para no desaprovechar ningún momento del día empieza a trabajar desde muy temprano y de lunes a domingo por la demanda que tiene, cuenta con un congelador en su casa y ahora lo único que le preocupa es que no tiene un puesto propio en el mercado para continuar con su labor.Para adquirir un espacio y continuar con su desempeño solicita la suma de 700 dólares en calidad de préstamo este monto le permitirá obtener una mejor ubicación y queda desde ya eternamente agradecida por vuestra cooperación

loans.use: To buy a stand in order to sell meat.

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
This business is run by Sri since 2006. She runs her business by renting her kiosk. At this moment her husband income is sufficient for her and their one child. As an employee in the private industry, with an income of Rp2000,000 (about US$220), and daily expense of Rp15,000 (about US$1.65), and child's education expense of Rp60,000 (about US$6.60)/month could be fulfilled. However, Sri is running the business in anticipation that daily expenses will increase. Sri's consumers are people around her kiosk. In that area Sri is not the only kiosk. This needs their own strategy. Competition in that area are quite stiff/positive. Pushed by increasing consumer's needs, she needs more capital. Her daily profit so far is about Rp40,000 (US$4.40).

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha ini telah dijalani Sri sejak tahun 2006. Dia menjalankan usahanya dengan cara mengontrak warung. Saat ini memang penghasilan suaminya sudah cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup dirinya dan seorang anak mereka, sebagai pegawai swasta dengan penghasilan per bulan Rp 2.000.000,00, biaya hidup per hari Rp 15.000.00 dan biaya pendidikan anak per bulan Rp 60.000,00 mampu dipenuhinya. Namun Sri menekuni usaha ini mengingat bahwa kebutuhan hidup mereka nantinya akan bertambah. Konsumennya Sri adalah masyarakat di sekitar warungnya. Di daerah tersebut Sri tidak jualan sendiri. Hal ini tentu memerlukan strategi tersendiri. Persaingan usaha di daerah tersebut cukup positif. Didorong oleh kebutuhan konsumen yang meningkat, maka dia membutuhkan modal usaha yang lebih besar. Setiap hari keuntungan yang diperoleh selama ini Rp 40.000,00.

loans.use:
To buy items for sale

Membeli barang-barang yang akan dijual.

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Đỗ Thị Tuyết is 50 years old and her husband is 52. They have 1 son and 3 daughters who are all grown up. Her husband works as a driver. Ms Tuyết has been participating in TYM fund for the last 8 years, she sells flowers and grocery at the market stand. This type of work is popular amongst the locals who live in the neighborhood of the market. Her income is about 4-5 USD a day. She really wishes to obtain a loan from TYM to be able to offer more variety to her customers. She's requesting a loan of 950 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Đỗ Thị Tuyết năm nay 50 tuổi, còn chồng chị 52. Họ có 1 con trai 3 con gái đều đã đến tuổi trưởng thành. Chồng chị là một người lái xe. Chị đã tham gia quỹ TYM được 8 năm nay, công việc chủ yếu của chị là bán hoa quả. Việc bán hàng hoa quả là một nghề phổ biến với người dân tại khu chợ nơi chị Tuyết sinh sống, công việc này thuận tiện cho việc hoàn trả tuần. Tiền lãi hàng ngày chị thu được từ nghề này khoảng 4-5USD. Chị rất muốn vay thêm vốn từ TYM để mua thêm nhiều hàng phục vụ cho người dân. Mức vốn đề nghị của chị lần này là 950USD

loans.use: Buy fruits, merchandise for her store

loans.name: José Otilio

texts.es:
Jose Otilio Santa Maria has a carpentry business, which he has run with a lot of effort for the last 30 years, located in the city of Chinadega in Chichigalpa. At an early age he was exposed to this line of work, he worked in a woodshop for a long time and he told us that this has been the only source of income for him and his family. Furthermore with the income he receives he is putting his older daughter through college.

Jose Otilio has a well deserve recognition in the area, he manages to keep excellent customers with his good work and high quality. Jose Otilio has been with CEPRODEL for four years and his very satisfied with the loans he has received, they all have come when he needed them the most. The loans helped him get the material needed for his business and this made him able to meet the deadlines for his clients and keep funding his daughter’s college career. He has repaid eight loans to date.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio al que se dedica el señor José Otilio S. G. es un taller de ebanistería que con mucho sacrificio ha venido desarrollando desde hace 30 años en la ciudad de Chinandega en Chichigalpa. Desde muy pequeño ha tenido experiencia en lo que respecta a este trabajo, ya que por muchísimo tiempo trabajó en un taller y nos cuenta que este negocio ha sido el único sustento para el y su familia. Además por medio del negocio beneficia a su hija que es estudiante universitaria.

Un merito muy grande que ha tenido el señor Otilio es que ha logrado captar varios clientes en su zona debido a que los trabajos de ebanistería los realiza muy finamente y con alta profesionalidad. Don José Otilio trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy satisfecho con los créditos otorgados pues se los han brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del taller de ebanistería y de esta manera poder satisfacer los pedidos de los clientes y seguir manteniendo los estudios universitarios de su hija. Actualmente tiene un record de 8 créditos.

loans.use:
Compra de madera y herramientas

Purchase wood and tools

loans.name: Tzonka

texts.en: Tzonka B. lives in the town of Smolian, Bulgaria. She was an accountant but three years ago started own business and founded a store which sells spare parts for cars. She started this business because her husband has a business selling second hand cars.  Tzonka’s husband helped her in the beginning, but now she works independently.  She has applied for $775 (1,000 BGN) in order to repair her store.

loans.use: For repairing the store.

loans.name: Chaquijya Central Group

texts.en:
Thirteen women make up the "Chaquijya Central" communal bank, a confident group who know each other well, and are ready to take out their second loan from Friendship Bridge. Gathered in the office in Sololá, they share about their businesses and dreams for the future.

Ten of the women are skilled in beading; crafting beautiful bracelets, necklaces, and earrings from tiny translucent beads, and selling them in the streets of nearby tourist towns, as well as through orders that friends and neighbors place. They will invest their loans in beads and string, which they purchase from a market in Sololá. Olga Tunay says that for the first time, with the help of their previous loan, they were able to buy beads in bulk, which drastically reduced the cost, as well as the number of trips they must make to the market.

Two women are skilled weavers, producing "huipiles" (the traditional Mayan blouse) and skirts like the ones in the picture. They will invest their loan in thread to weave these intricate clothes. A single huipil can take up to three months to make, and after an initial investment of $30-$50, it can be sold for up to $200. These huipiles represent a woman's home town, her marital status, and other interests and beliefs.

Three women have second businesses, in addition to their crafts. Marcela Y. also raises chickens to add to her beading income. Elena C. grows vegetables, such as corn, potatoes, and milpa (the leaves that are used to wrap tamales). And Olga Tunay has a panadería (a bakery), where she bakes fresh bread daily that is sold to local stores. She is well known in her community and regular customers stop by all day to purchase bread.

The women are very pleased with the direction in which their businesses are headed, and are now dreaming of the future. Their main goal is "seguir adelante," to keep moving forward, in order to proviD. better for their families and offer their children the educations they weren’t able to have. To achieve this, they hope someday to open stores where they can sell their jewelry and clothing. Olga would like to open another bakery, Marcela would like to raise animals besides chickens, and others would like to begin additional businesses, like raising animals or selling tortillas. They are learning to save money for the future that will help them with these goals.

The women of Chaquijya Central express their happiness in being a part of Friendship Bridge. They have seen other banks, and are grateful for the low interest rate and education they receive here. In addition to being a source capital, they have also found friendship and community. They are asking for a group loan of 30,500 quetzales (about $4,025 USD) that they will pay back over 9 months.

loans.use: To purchase beads and thread, as well as invest in a bakery, chickens, and vegetable cultivation

loans.name: Mujeres En Progreso Group

texts.en:
Aridaysi is a 28 year old woman who lives in the small community of Guaricanos, located on the outskirts of the capital of Santo Domingo. She lives with her husband and five children, and is taking out her first loan to start her own micro-business.

She plans to use the money to start a small business selling new clothing to her community members. In her community, L. Guaricanos, the majority of the people live very poorly, but there are a few who have enough money to buy new clothes and for that very reason she sees an opportunity to start a business to meet a need that often goes unmet. She says that she hopes in a few years her business will have done so well that she will be able to own her own store where people come to her for her clothes. For her family, she hopes to see her children become prepared professionals and responsible adults, and to one day in the near future buy a home they can call their own.

Although things can often be very challenging and trying, Aridaysi says that she knows she is hard working, and that this loan will help her achieve her dreams.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Aridaysi herself, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To start a new business selling new clothing to her community members.

loans.name: Jeny

texts.es:
Jeny belongs to the Communal Bank “Luis Pardo II,” and she has Internet and phone cabins in her home. Her business is in Chiquian district, Bolognesi province, Ancash state.

With the S/.900 nuevos soles loan, which will be repaid in 6 payments, she will buy rechargeable phone cards.

She is 23 years old, married, and is expecting her first child. Her husband helps her with this business and they meet their household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Jeny, pertenece al Banco Comunal Luis Pardo II, tiene sus cabinas de Internet y locutorio en su casa, en el distrito Chiquian, provincia de Bolognesi, departamento de Ancash.

Con el préstamo de S/. 900.00 nuevos soles , el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará recarga virtual.

Ella tienen 23 años de edad, casada, esta esperando su primer bebé, su esposo le ayuda en este negocio y solventan los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Purchase phone cards for her business

loans.name: Nal

texts.en: Nal N., 20, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Soeun Sim, and their one young child. She is a farmer who typically makes US$1.60 working the fields, while her husband  is also a farmer who grows cucumber and rice, making US$2.30 each day. This has been a difficult year for farmers in Cambodia, because weather patterns have not been as consistent and inflation has been high. Many families are seeking out loans to expand and diversify their sources of income. Nal N. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase ducks to breed for eggs. She sees this as the beginning of a business that would expand and, in the future, she would like to have a lot of ducks to generate many eggs. Duck eggs are a popular food here in Cambodia and she is confident that once the business starts, her customer base will grow rapidly.

loans.use: To purchase ducks

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar H. is a 23-year-old young man who lives with his family in Ningarhar province. He is married and has two children. They are small and don't go to school yet. Omar lives with his brothers at one home and they support their family together. Omar is illiterate but he admires educated people. He thus advises his brothers to care more about their studying and to work hard.

Omar H. has been working as a farmer for the last several years on his own land. He doesn't have a lot of land but he is a very active and hardworking man. He grows wheat, tomatoes, eggplants, and other different kinds of vegetables. He takes them to the marketplace for sale. Actually his current income is just 300 Afghanis ($6) a day and it's too little to suffice for his household expenditures.

Omar says that he has fertile land in an area close to the city which is a great benefit logistically. But he is in need of cash to purchase seeds and fertilizers. He has therefore applied for a 30,000 Afghanis loan.

Omar H. hopes that after a few months he will see a lot of positive changes in his business and thus in his family conditions. He is also dreaming about enrolling his brothers in private educational schools which are much better than public schools. He promised that he will repay this loan in 24 months in a timely fashion.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is married. She has 4 children, aged 14, 22, 26 and 28 years. She has a business selling spices and has been doing so since 2004. Each day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Khadija now hopes for a loan to buy more spices for her business.

loans.use: To buy more spices for her business.

loans.name: Gonzalo Daniel

texts.es: El señor Gonzalo, no cuenta con trabajo formal desde hace varios años, por lo que su único ingreso económico es el que le proporciona su pequeña tienda de barrio, con ese ingreso mantiene a toda su familia. Su esposa, que tampoco cuenta con otro medio de ingreso, le ayuda en la atención de la tienda, tienen dos hijos en edad escolar, a quienes cuidan con mucho cariño. Toda la familia vive en la casa de los padres del señor Gonzalo, ya que la tienda no es propia y tiene tiene que pagar los alquileres mensuales. Este crédito servirá para aumentar el stock de abarrotes y conservas, para la venta.
texts.en:
Mr. Gonzalo hasn't had regular employment for many years; his only form of income stems from his small neighborhood store. This income supports his whole family. His wife, who also doesn't have another source of income, helps him in the store. They have two school-aged children that they take care of with much love. The whole family lives in Mr. Gonzalo's parents' house as they don't own the store and must pay rent for the locale monthly. This loan will be used to increase the grocery and non-perishable stocks for sale.

Translated from Spanish by Liz West, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries and non-perishables for sale.

loans.name: Phy

texts.en:
Mrs. Phy M., 31, is a farmer in Ta Skaom Village in the Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Lach Man, is a construction worker who makes a small income. Although Mrs. Phy M. and her husband have income from different businesses, they still live in poor conditions and in an old house.

In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Phy M. decided to ask for a loan to buy timbers to build a new house for her family. The couple has four children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the remaining two stay at home to help their parents. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy timbers to build a new house for the family.

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi: Chị Vân  năm nay 30 tuổi hiện chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con tại Huyện Mê Linh tỉnh Vĩnh Phúc. Năm 2004 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào công việc buôn bán phế liệu. Hiện nay ngoài  buôn bán phế liệu gia đình chị Vân còn đầu tư vốn chăn nuôi lợn để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình . Với sự giúp đỡ của chồng công việc chăn nuôi , buôn bán của gia đình chị đang phát triển rất thuận lợi. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua hêm 2 con lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. V. Thi Ngo, 30 years old, currently lives with her husband and children in Me Linh, Vinh Phuc. In 2004 she joined the Fund and borrowed money to invest in a recycling business. Currently besides trading recycled materials, her family also raise livestock to increase the family's income. With the help of her husband in the livestock work, the business is expanding and doing very well. In this round of funding she is requesting 15 million VND to invest in buying 2 large pigs and feed to serve the livestock needs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pigs and feed

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia tiene 25 años de edad, vive junto a su hijo y a su conviviente quienes la apoyan en todo, sobre todo en sus propósitos para la mejora de su negocio. Se dedica a la venta de ropa usada, la lleva a vender por los distintos caseríos de su localidad, dejándola al crédito o al contado, esta labor la viene realizando desde hace ya dos años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer muchos lugares y dar una muy buena atención a sus clientes. Le es rentable porque las prendas que vende son solo por pedidos, debido a ya cuenta con sus clientes selectos. Este es su 2do préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más prendas, posteriormente quiere alquilar un puesto en el mercado para poner su tienda.
texts.en:
Julia is 25 years old and lives with her son and husband, who help her with everything, especially the improvement of her business. She sells used clothing, which she carries to different villages in her area to sell for credit or cash, and has been doing so for the past two years. What she likes about her work is getting to know many places and giving her customers a lot of attention. It is profitable because the garments are sold only through orders, already selected by the customers. This is her second loan from MFP, and she has demonstrated responsibility with her payments. With this money, she will buy more garments, and later she would like to rent a space in the market for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the quantity of garments for sale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha O. is a 36-year-old woman living in the Stella B area of the Rongo District in Kenya. She has been married since 1988 to a driver who works with the local Superfoam Mattress Company. Together, Martha and her husband have 7 children, all of whom are currently enrolled in school. 

Martha has one business selling fresh milk and a second business selling new clothes. Martha buys the fresh milk in bulk from the locally owned Oyami farm and she sells the milk to the community.  For her second business, Martha purchases mainly children’s clothing from the towns of Migori and Kisii, and sells the items in the nearest market. 

Martha started her milk business in 2004, using her own savings as start-up capital. The new clothes enterprise was started with a boost from her husband and from a K-MET loan. 

With the benefits from her previous K-MET loan and her two businesses, Martha makes enough profit to pay the school fees for her seven children, meet her household expenses, and pay for any necessary medical expenses. 

Martha is requesting a loan of KSH 15,000 ($200 USD ) to purchase more clothing for her clothing business. She would like to increase her stock so she has more items for the new year.

loans.use: To purchase clothing items

loans.name: Mahtab Nadera Group

texts.en: Mahtab Gul is the leader of the Mahtab Nadera group. The group members live in the 15th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. There are three members in this group. They want to take the loan for their business progress. Mahtab Gul wants to take a loan to buy wood and other required materials for her bakery. M.'s father wants to buy wood for his carpentry shop and Nadera wants to take a loan for her husband’s fruit cart. They all say that this loan will help them so much to grow.

loans.use: To buy various materials

loans.name: Las Salvadoras Group

texts.es:
Es un banco comunal compuesto D. 17 personas, el cual pertenece a la Localidad del km.9 a la ciudad D. Santa Cruz, la mayoría D. los clientes se dedican al comercio D. ropa, cosméticos, frutas y venta D. comidas.
GIOVANNA L. V..- es la líder del banco ella vive en el Km.9 en el barrio 4 D. marzo cuenta con casa propia. 
Su actividad principal es la venta D. cosméticos con lo que viene trabajado desD. hace aproximadamente tres años, es una persona muy responsable, le gusta trabajar con señoras para compartir sus experiencias y conocimientos.
LUZMILA BETHZABE Q..- es la secretaria del banco comunal. La actividad a la que se dedica es la venta D. comida venD. en su mismo domicilio hace unos tres años aproximadamente. Vive en la casa D. sus padres con su hijo y es madre soltera.
Su sueño es colocar en el Km.9 un restaurante propio, para así mejorar sus ingresos y poder darles una vida mejor a sus hijos ya que ellos se encuentran estudiando.  
CLAUDIA G. V..-  La Sra. Claudia es la Tesorera del banco comunal. Su actividad principal es la venta D. cosméticos por medio D. revistas (promotora), hace un año que viene trabajando con el mismo, y como segunda actividad tiene la D. la elaboración D. pan, es decir trabaja como ayudante en la cual su ganancias es en porcentajes.
Su meta es seguir trabajando, “el dinero que me fue desembolsado con este préstamo es el inicio una actividad mas”, comentó.
texts.en:
This is a community bank maD. up of 17 people, which is part of the locality known as "Km 9" near the city of Santa Cruz. The majority of the clients sell clothing, cosmetics, fruits and foods. GIOVANNA L. VIDUARRE is leader of the bank. She lives in Km 9, in the "4th of March" neighborhood and has her own house. Her main job is cosmetic sales. For about three years she has worked in this. She is a very responsible person. She likes working together with the women to share their experiences and knowledge. LUZMILA BETHZABE Q. is secretary of the community bank. She sells food. For about three years, she has worked from the same location. She lives in her parent’s house with her son and is a single mother. Her dream is to open her own restaurant in Km 9, in order to increase her income and to be able to give a better life to her children who are already studying. CLAUDIA G. VIDUARRE – Claudia is the treasurer of the community bank. Her main job is selling cosmetics through magazine ads. For one year, she has worked in this. Her second job is baking bread. She works as an apprentice so her earnings are in percentages. Her goal is to keep working. “The money that is paid out to me with this loan is the beginning of another job,” she said.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Ruth M.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 42-year old Ruth M. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 12 and 20. She also supports one dependant because he is an orphan. Ruth has been running a local restaurant known as “mama lishe” since 2008. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.
She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and one employee assists her. Ruth currently earns about $120 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD in order to buy rice, beans, flour, cooking oil, and sugar in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to to open the same business at a new location. Ruth thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, flour, cooking oil, and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Leonel Edgardo

texts.es: Leonel Edgardo C. vive en la Colonia santísima trinidad departamento San Salvador, Leonel tiene  30 años de edad, está acompañado  y tiene dos hijos, uno de ellos tiene  10 años y otro 5 años, ambos niños van a la escuela;  Leonel se dedica a su negocio que una venta de tortas, ubicado en un pequeño puesto que está rodeado por muchas oficinas donde los empleados salen a la hora del almuerzo y compran de sus tortas, Leonel cuenta con el apoyo de su compañera de vida que le ayuda en el negocio todos los días, Leonel solicita un crédito para la compra de materia prima como carnes, jamones, pan. De esta manera podrá incrementar sus ventas y por consiguientes sus ganancias, las cuales son el único ingreso con el que cuenta esta familia
texts.en:
Leonel Edgardo C. lives in the Santisima Trinidad neighborhood of San Salvador department. He is 30 years old, has a life partner and two children aged 10 and 5, both of whom go to school. Leonel sells tortas from a small stand which is in a business district where many employees come out at lunch time to buy tortas from him. His life companion helps him with this endeavor every day. Leonel is asking for a loan to buy raw materials such as meats, ham and bread so that he can increase his sales and therby his profits which are the sole source of income for the family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 40 years old and she is married with 5 children. She sells provisions and foodstuffs. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kwame

texts.en: Kwame A. is 36 years old, and is married with three children who are currently in school. He is a retailer of car spare parts, which he buys from his suppliers and retails to his customers. Kwame does not have adequate funds to support his business, especially in the phase of recent price hikes. He therefore needs a loan to remain in business. With the loan, he wants to purchase new stock of spare parts and scraps to serve his customers. Kwame believes the loan will enable him to save more for his children education and also build his own shop.

loans.use: To purchase new stock of spare parts and scraps.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet S. sells medicines to make a living. She is 36 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thanks to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana A. is 43 years old, married and has four children—a daughter and three sons. Some are currently in the senior high school and some are in the the junior high and primary schools. The family lives in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in the Western Region. Her husband is a cocoa farmer. She sells food items such as plantain, cassava, yam, and so forth. She buys her goods from nearby communities at affordable prices and sells them in the market square in her community to chop bar operators and other retailers. Susana also treks to other markets to sell her products. She has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. Susana aspires to expand her business and sponsor her children in school.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tomatoes, bananas and soap

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
Anita  es socia del Bancomunal  las empresarias.
Anita es conviviente tiene 40 años, tiene dos hijos de 17 y 3 años, el mayor esta en la escuela estatal.
Anita  trabajaba en una empresa de plásticos, lo dejo por que salio embarazada, después de un tiempo le regalaron una vitrina y le dio la idea de vender  en su casa, compro  dulces,  ropas productos de belleza, joyas desde hace un año.
Desde que Anita esta en Finca aprendió a invertir y sobre todo en que tiene que invertir, ella solo pide lo que va poder pagar. 
Anita necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de productos de belleza por catalogo,  de ropa y joyas.
El sueño de Anita es tener una tienda grande donde pueda vender sus productos.
texts.en:
Anita is a member of the communal bank group “Las Empresarias”. She is 40 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 2 children (ages 17 & 3). The oldest child attends a state school.

Anita worked at a plastics company but left after she became pregnant. About a year ago, she was given a glass display case as a gift and thought it would be a good idea to start a home business selling candy, clothes, beauty products and jewelry.

Since joining FINCA, she has learned to invest and knows what it takes to run her business. Anita needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy beauty products from a catalog, clothing, and jewelry. She dreams of opening a large store where she can sell her products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products by catalog, clothing & jewelry

loans.name: Falala

texts.en:
Falala E. is a 48-year-old woman who lives in Samalaeulu Leauvaa.  She is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Falala runs a bakery where she bakes & sells a variety of baked goods to the local community.  Falala has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Falala joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Falala is requesting for the first time a loan from SPBD.    Falala is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients.  This will be her first loan from SPBD.  Falala plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders."

loans.use: To purchase additional cooking ingredients

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites P. is a 34 year old widow who owns and manages a small store in front of her house. She has been in this business for four years and she is thankful for the continuous operation of her store.  Marites admits that being a widow is not that easy. She serves as the father and mother to her two children who were both studying.  Her husband passed away when their youngest was only ten months old.  Now, her youngest is  8 years old and her eldest is ten years old.  They are presently residing in the village of Anguapan Tumauini, Isabela, a place which is a little distant from the public market. 

Marites is looking forward to the success of her business and hoping to support the education of her children.  Marites is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to be used in purchasing the needed commodities she sells in her store. According to her she will do everything to make her business gain more income because this is the only source of income that she has.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Las Palmeras Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer “German Busch”, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal “Palmeras”, con  9 integrantes, se agruparon recientemente  para acceder al préstamo, su presidenta es Eloiza M. y espera que el grupo siga adelante y se mantenga en el tiempo. 
Venta de celulares, jugo de quinua, colchas, carne, comida, tapiz  y helado son los negocios de las integranes y necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercaderia e insumos, un ejemplo claro es Isabel Y. de 37 años tiene el negocio de heladería, en su domicilio y necesita el préstamo para comprar insumos como leche y saborizantes.

loans.use: COMPRA DE MERCADERIA E INSUMOS

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 56 años, vive con su hijo de 18 años en su casa propia. Desde hace 20 años se dedica a las tareas agrícolas y a la venta de animales como cuyes y pollos. Para esto, diariamente se dirige a las distintas ferias comerciales de los pueblos aledaños a su localidad para ofrecer sus animales y los fines de semana, en las ferias ganaderas. Maria compra estos animales de una granja, pero también tiene una cantidad que ella misma cría. Este negocio le ha permitido educar a su hijo y sostener los gastos que se requiere su hogar, aun a pesar de las temporadas de ventas bajas, pues su capacidad para el comercio le ha permitido concretar las ventas necesarias para cubrir sus gastos. Para el futuro, Maria desea empezar a vender animales más grandes, como vacas y ovejas.
Esta es la novena oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella se siente muy contenta de ser parte de su banco comunal, por lo que está comprometida en ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. El dinero que viene solicitando será para invertido en la compra de mayor cantidad de cuyes y pollos.
texts.en:
Maria is 56 years old and lives with her son, who is 18 years old, in her own house. For 20 years, she has done agricultural work and sold animals, like guinea pigs and chickens. For this, every day she goes to different commercial fairs in towns near her area to sell her animals. During the weekends, she sells her animals in the cattle fairs. Maria buys these animals from a farm, but she also has some animals that she raises. This business has allowed her to educate her son and to pay for the household expenses, in spite of seasons of low sales. Her capacity for trade has allowed her to make the necessary sales to cover her expenses. For the future, Maria wants to begin selling larger animals, like cows and sheep. This is her ninth loan with MFP. She feels very happy to be part of her community bank. She is dedicated to being punctual with the repayments of her loan. The money that she is requesting will be used to invest in the purchase of more guinea pigs and chickens.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more animals

loans.name: Juvelyn

texts.en: Juvelyn A. is from the village of Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Juvelyn owns and operates a tailoring business, providing women’s tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Juvelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Juvelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Blanca María

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Blanca María E. le está haciendo falta un cambiar el techo ya que el actual está en muy malas condiciones. Es por eso que solicita el préstamo para poder repararlo, pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de construir el nuevo techo. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el sueldo de su trabaja como enfermera de una institución gubernamental, ya que su esposo el señor Julio Cesar E. se encargara de los gastos familiares con su ingreso de su trabajo como jefe de departamento del seguro social de Nuevo Laredo. 
Desea tener la casa que le dejaron sus padres en buenas condiciones
texts.en:
Blanca María E.'s house needs a new roof since the current one is in very bad condition. Thus, she is requesting funds to repair it since she does not have the wherewithall to buy materials and pay the person who will install the new roof. She intends to repay the loan using the salary she earns as a nurse in a state institution since her husband, Julio Cesar E., will see to the household expenses with his salary earned as a department head at the Nuevo Laredo Social Security. She hopes to keep the house her parents left her in good condition.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To replace her wood roof.

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
José tiene 44 años, es una persona muy risueña, tiene 4 hijos y vive con su pareja en su casa propia.
Años atrás se proyectó al futuro elaborando 5 viveros de grandes extensiones, de los cuales una parte vendió y la otra la trasplantó en sus chacras, pero nada le hizo presagiar que la plaga de mosquitos atacarían las hojas de sus cultivos y no la pudo controlar a tiempo, perdiendo muchos granos de café. Por ello, sus cosechas el año pasado mermaron notablemente pese a toda la dedicación y empeño puesta en ellas. A pesar de la tristeza, José cree que no todo está perdido, pues cree que podrá recuperarlas durante este año o tal vez el próximo, menciona. 
Sin embargo, el también cuenta con una chacra de plátanos, a la cual no le tenía mucha fe, pero hoy es con esta fruta con la que logra cubrir la alimentación y educación de sus hijos. 

En vista de que quiere recuperar sus cultivos, solicita este primer crédito a MFP, asimismo se compromete a pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que está muy agradecido por permitirle ser parte de un banco comunal. Con el dinero comprará fungicidas para erradicar los mosquitos y si le alcanza adquirirá semillas de café para hacer un vivero.
texts.en:
José, 44, is a very cheerful person. He has 4 children and lives with his partner in his own home. Years ago he planned his future by building five large nurseries from which he sold part of the product and part he transplanted to his own farmlands. But nothing prepared him for the mosquito plague that would attack the leaves of his crops and he was unable to control it in time losing many coffee beans as a result. For this reason, his crop yields last year were greatly diminished despite his dedication and hard work. Despite the sadness, José believes that all is not lost because, as he states, he feels he can salvage them this year or next year, perhaps. However, he also planted some bananas; a crop upon which he didn't have great expectations. However, it is precisely this fruit which allows him to provide his children with food and schooling. Since he wants to salvage his crops, he is asking MFP for his first loan which he pledges to repay in a timely fashion since he is very grateful to be allowed to be part of a communal bank. With the funds he will buy fungicides to erradicate the mosquitoes and, if he has any money left over, will buy coffee seeds to start a new nursery.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fungicides.

loans.name: Pita

texts.en:
Pita J. is currently in the business of selling food in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase drinks like sodas, water, packed juice, etc., to sell. Pita is 28 years old and single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase drinks like sodas, water, packed juice, etc.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny C. is from the village of Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old. Jenny is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jenny owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling cosmetics, clothing and shoe products in the local community. Jenny has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jenny joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenny is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jenny from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luafalealii

texts.en:
Luafalealii T. is 35 and married with 1 child (4 years-old).  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Luafalealii has 3 years of experience in this business.  Luafalealii needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Luafalealii joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Luafalealii's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Luafalealii's Social Metrics provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.9 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Baby Jane

texts.en:
Baby Jane is a 30-year-old rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She is now preparing her land for planting and needs seeds, fertilizers and farm inputs to be able to have an abundant harvest. According to her, she really needs to earn because her children are going to school.

Baby Jane applied for a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use this loan to fund her farm: she will be able to purchase the necessary inputs needed at her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mary Joy Beth

texts.en:
Mary Joy Beth Q. is from the village of Tangaro, Catarman Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Mary Joy Beth is married and has 1 school-aged child. Mary Joy Beth owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food & daily use products. Mary Joy Beth has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Mary Joy Beth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Joy Beth is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Mary Joy Beth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tumurchudur

texts.en: Tumurchudur is 34 years old and lives with her husband and their three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family have lived in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, for 6 years. Tumurchudur and her husband have been operating a mobile food trading business out of their  car since 2005. When the business first started their working capital was 400,000 tugrugs (~ 281 USD). However, as a result of their hard work and determination, their working capital has increased to 1,200,000 (~ 844 USD). Since Tumirchudur and her husband started the business their quality of life has improved and they have purchased a new car and are building a house for their family. Tumurchudur and her husband plan to expand their business in the future. Tumurchudur is an open person who has a great communication skills.  She says, “I would like to provide my children with a good education and bring them up them in the proper way.”  She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 351 USD) loan to purchase a variety of food products such as flour and rice to resell in the countryside for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products

loans.name: Kyosimba Onanya, Kibuga, Mpigi Group

texts.en:
N. Sarah is shown at the top right in the small photo and also appears in the group photo. She is a 45-year-old married mother of six who runs a retail shop business in Kibugga, Mpigi district.

This hardworking woman has been running her business for eleven years now and attributes her success to the return value chord she has struck with her customers. Her monthly cash inflow projections are at 100,000 shillings.

With this loan Sarah thinks she can increase what she earns in a month by almost 50%. Her mission is to expand her retail business in the short term by restocking her shop with more general merchandise.

loans.use: To restock her shop with more general merchandise

loans.name: Shery

texts.en:
Shery A. is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Shery is separated from her spouse and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Shery owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Shery has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Shery joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shery is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Shery from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sinforosa

texts.es:
Sinforosa, tiene 56 años, tiene 7 hijos, vive en la comunidad de Inquilpatae del distrito de Anta del departamento del Cusco. Su principal actividad económica es vender queso y granos secos en el Campo Ferial de la Comunidad Campesina de Inquilpata-Anta.  Ella nos cuenta que también envía sus productos a la ciudad de Nazca. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo.  

Sinforosa es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario ayudar a su familia, ella requiere el crédito para comprar semillas y comprar algunos animales menores. 
 
Sinforosa pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN MARIA DE INQUILPATA” de la Asociación Arariwa. El banco comunal tiene 4 ciclos de funcionamiento, la socia manifiesta, que se encuentra contenta y satisfecha con los servicios de crédito, ahorro y capacitación que brinda la Asociación.  

Sinforosa se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. La comunidad de Inquilpata se encuentra a una hora y diez minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Sinforosa, aged 56, is the mother of seven children. She lives in the neighborhood of Inquilpata in the district of Anta of the department of Cusco. Her main economic activity consists in selling cheese and dry beans at the trade fair of the rural community of Inquilpata-Anta. She told us that she also ships her goods to the city of Nazca. She has been in this business for several years so far and is doing very well thanks to her determination. Sinforosa is a hardworking and enterprising mother who seeks at all times to succeed and help her family thanks to her daily efforts. She applies for this loan to buy seeds and a few small animals. Sinforosa is a member of the community bank "Virgen María de Inquilpata" of the microfinance institution Asociación Arariwa. The community bank has four cycles of operation, Sinforosa explained and stated at the same time that she is happy and satisfied with the services that Asociación Arariwa offers in terms of loans, savings and training sessions. Sinforosa is thankful for the opportunity provided by this loan and is committed to the loan repayment schedule. The neighborhood of Inquilpata is located one hour and ten minutes from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and a few small animals

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila D. is from the village of Barangay Villaros, Bagabag, Neuva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Mila is widowed and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Mila owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mila is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Mila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Lingueres Fallokh Serere Group

texts.fr: Le groupe lingueres de FALLOKH SERERE groupe de cinq (5) vendeuses de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis cinq (5) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de deux cent francs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.
texts.en:
The “Lingueres de Fallokh Serere” group consists of five retailers of vegetables and condiments from a neighbourhood market in the town of Mbour. This group was created five years ago, requiring that daily fees of 200 CFA be collected from each member and given to one of the members on a rotating basis. This sum is then used in the commercial activities to bolster the group’s working capital. As these daily fees proved insufficient to support the working capital, the group requested a loan. Most group members have left their home village to settle in town and earn enough to feed their families.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: commercial activity

loans.name: Chita

texts.en: Mr. Chita S. is 40 years old and lives in Smaong Village in Takeo Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Srytouch Cheng, are farmers who own 1.50 hectares of land upon which they cultivate rice. He is also a cow middleman, earning additional income to support the family.  Chita is now requesting a loan to buy ten piglets and pig food for pig breeding in order to improve the family's living standard. This couple has three children, all students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and pig food

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
El señor Juan Carlos O. A. tiene 34 años de edad y vive en el barrio Florida de la ciudad de Tarija. Juan aun no se caso y vive en casa de su madre, Juan  desde hace mas de 5 años que se dedica al servicio de transporte de pasajeros y es socio del  sindicato de taxi trufis el Chapaco.  
                                                                                                                                                                                                   Juan quisiera formar una familia, tener hijos y en un futuro nietos, el nos cuenta que la casa donde vive es de adobe, construcción que es muy antigua y quisiera construir algunas habitaciones donde puedan vivir cómodos sus hermanos y su madre. 

El crédito que está solicitando es para la compra de repuestos para su vehículo, para de ese modo seguir trabajando con su taxi.  
              
Juan nos cuenta que su mayor sueño es poder darles toda la comodidad que pueda a sus hermanos y su madre. También nos dice que el próximo crédito que solicite será para la compra de otra movilidad de esa forma poder mejorar las condiciones  económicas en su hogar.
texts.en:
Sr. Juan Carlos O. A. is 34 years old and lives in the Florida neighborhood of the city of Tarija. He is still not married and lives at his mother’s house. For more than five years, Juan has been providing passenger transport services and is a member of the Chapaco taxi drivers union.

Juan wants to start a family, have children, and see future grandchildren. He says he lives in an adobe house that was constructed a long time ago, so he wants to build additional rooms so that his siblings and his mother will be more comfortable.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy spare parts for his vehicle so that he can continue working as a taxi driver. Juan says that his greatest wish is to provide all the comforts for his siblings and his mother. In addition, he indicates that the next loan he requests will be used to buy another vehicle so that he can improve the financial conditions of his household.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina describes herself as a persevering and hardworking woman. She has been operating her retail food business for the past two years, specializing in rice and stew. She sells meals such as these to day-laborers and individuals in her neighborhood.

Currently, Augustina operates her business from a kiosk on the side of the road. She is excited to be taking out this loan so that she can purchase cooking materials that will help her meet her customers’ demand: bags of rice, cooking oil, tomatoes and seasonings. She dreams of generating enough profits to support the education of her children.

In addition to being a vibrant entrepreneur, Augustina, 49, is also married to a commercial driver and together they have seven children ranging in age from 15 to 28 years.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old married man and has 2 young children; he is from Lebanon. For the past 22 years, he has been working in a car repair shop. He is the main provider for his wife and kids. He works hard to earn the profit needed to pay for his children's schooling. Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1,800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. It will be his second loan and is intended to buy additional spare parts and motor oils required by his clients. In the future, he is looking to continue the expansion of his business and to further increase his productivity. He expects that his business will continue to be successful in the coming year.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: buy additional spare parts and motor oils

loans.name: Nelyvin Makungu

texts.en:
Nelyvin Makungu S. is a woman of 31 years and a single parent. She lives with four of her relatives in Likuyani in the outskirts of Eldoret. Nelyvin offers motorbike transport to people in Likuyani; she has also employed a young man to help in her transportation work. Most of her customers are her neighbors. She has been in this business for two years and she gets a monthly income of 15,000 shillings.

Nelyvin will be taking her second loan with KADET and she plans to use the loan to buy new spare parts and carry out major repairs for her motorbike and also to buy new iron sheets for roofing her house.

With the profit she is going to get, she plans to buy another motorbike to increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for the motorbike

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es:
Maria Elizabeth A. P. tiene 26 anos. Es soltera y vive en el cantón de Guaranda en la provincia Bolívar de Ecuador. Tiene 1 hija de 4 anos. 

Maria es socia de la ventanilla rural Gradas Chico, que está ubicada a quince minutos en carro de la ciudad de Guaranda. Son 20 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican al cultivo de maíz, trigo, papas, y la cría de animales.  Este es el tercer préstamo que sacan con la cooperativa.

A Maria trabaja como empleada domestica en Quito y en la agricultura en su comunidad. Solicita el credito para comprar una baca. Con el apoyo del credito le ayudaria en vender la leche de la baca. Su sueno es tener un negocio de venta de ropa. Se deafia por la falta de dinero en su vida. 

Le gusta pasar tiempo con su hijo.
texts.en:
Maria Elizabeth A. P. is 26 years old. She is single and lives in the canton of Guaranda , part of the Bolivar province in Ecuador. She has one 4-year-old daughter. Erlinda is member of the Gradas Chico rural bank, which is located 15 minutes by car from the city of Guaranda. There are 20 members in total, who for the most part dedicate themselves to growing corn, wheat, potatoes and the breeding of animals. This is the third loan taken out with the cooperative. Maria works as a domestic employee in Quito and as an agricultural worker in her community. She is requesting the loan to buy a cow. Support from the loan would help her to sell the cow’s milk. Her dream is to have a commerce selling clothes. She is confronted by the lack of funds in her life. She likes to spend time with her child.

Translated from Spanish by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy a cow

loans.name: Brima

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Brima.  He is married, and has one child aged six. He has nine additional dependents.   In the year 2000, Brima established his Provisions business selling milk, sugar, butter, tea, sardines, etc. He began his business because he wanted to improve the standard of living of himself and his family. 

Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, he earns about 1,300,000SLL every month from this business. He needs a loan of 4,000,000SLL. Brima requires a loan to be able to buy his goods in bulk so that his can make more profit. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 300,000SSL. 

In the future, Brima plans to educate his child to university level and buy a piece of land, rent a shop, hire a salesperson, and sell his goods wholesale. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for his provisions shop

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es: Doña María es de 29 años de edad, Casada, tiene tres hijas, se dedica a la actividad de costurera/sastre, en la actividad tiene más de 2 años de experiencia y ve bien con este trabajo, ya que devenga de este los gastos familiares y otros gastos, solicita su segundo crédito  para  la compra de terreno que le sirve para el bienestar de su familia, ya que su sueño es que sus hijas tengan un lugar donde vivir cuando sean grandes, los creditos anteriores los pago sin problemas de atrasos y de acuerdo a la actividad a la que se dedica podrá realizar sus pagos en el credito actual. De esta manera ella contribuye al desarrollo de su familia y la sociedad.
texts.en:
María Guadalupe Y. T. 
María is 29 years old, married, and has three daughters.  She makes a living as a seamstress/tailor, and already has more than two years of experience in this trade.  She is now requesting her second loan so that she can purchase land, which will be a worthwhile investment.  Through her work she will be able to make her payments without any problems.

loans.use: Purchasing some land or assets

loans.name: Paul Ochiel

texts.en:
Paul has been in auto repair in Naivasha town since 1996.  He is 35 years old, married to Hellen Akinyi and they have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He paid his first loan of Kshs 15,000 well and in good time.  He plans to buy a battery charger and open a clothes shop for his wife with the loan.

In the future, Paul hopes to open his own auto garage and be self-employed.

loans.use: To buy a battery charger and open a clothes shop for his wife.

loans.name: Rudh Secibel

texts.es:
Rudh de 28 años, , ella tiene una papelería (en Ecuador se los llama “bazar”), vive en el Suburbio de Guayaquil(zona urbana, la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales). 

La hermana mayor se fue al migro a oto país y le dejo en el cuidado de su casa y una papelería para poder mantener a su familia se puso administrar el negocio, vendiendo cuadernos, plumas y papeles a sus vecinos y conocidos Trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 21h00pm todos los días.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar un congelador para vender bebidas y  cuadernos, plumas para su negocio. En el futuro quiere amplia la papelería.
texts.en:
28-year old Rudh runs a stationery store (called a bazaar in Ecuador). She lives on the outskirts of Guayaquil, a suburban area where the majority of people have informal businesses.

Rudh’s eldest sister emigrated to another country leaving Rudh to look after her house and the stationery store as a means of supporting the family. Rudh started selling notebooks, pens, and paper to her neighbours and friends. She works from 7am to 9pm every day.

With the loan, she plans to buy a freezer so she can sell cold drinks, as well as more notebooks and pens. Her future plan is to expand the store.

loans.use: to buy a freezer and more stationery

loans.name: Ramon Antonio

texts.es:
el sr. Ramon P. cuenta con una tienda en la cual vende abarrotería en general denominada DESPENSA EL HOGAR. su negocio esta al servicio de la población del municipio de Las Trojes ofreciéndoles productos de la canasta básica familiar a los mejores precios del mercado, tanto al por mayor como al detalle, contando con mas de un año de experiencia en el manejo de esta actividad comercial, su negocio esta ubicado en la calle denominada del comercio lugar estratégico donde se ubica la mayor parte de los negocios de este municipio.       
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercaderia y asi surtir bien su negocio, ya que la demanda de sus clientes es bastante. 
las ganancias las necesita para salir adelante con su familia.
texts.en:
Ramon P. has a store in which he sells general groceries.  His store is called “Despensa el Hogar” (Home Pantry)  His business serves the population of the town of Las Trojes, offering them products from the basic family shopping basket at the best prices on the market both wholesale and retail.  He has more than a year of experience in this business activity.  His business is located in a commercial street.  It is a strategic place where most of the businesses of the town are to be found.

He will use his loan to buy merchandise and thereby better stock his business since his customers' demand is quite high.

He needs the profits he makes to get his family ahead.

loans.use: To buy butter, rice, beans, flour, oil, margarine, salt, milk, soft drinks, sugar, bread, cookies, juice, soap, toilet paper, sanitary towels, candies, churros, soup and pasta

loans.name: Wellingtone

texts.en:
Wellingtone O. is 56 years old from Khwisero area in Kakamega. He is married to Lona and they have two children who are in college; aged 24 and 20 years old.

Wellingtone is a tailor in the market of Khwisero and has been in this business for the past 12 years. He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is also a client here. He wants to use the money to buy another sewing machine as the one he has is old and is not functioning well. He is also getting ready for the festive season where orders for making new clothes are many.

His desire is to be able to open up a tailoring school in the future.

loans.use: Buy another sewing machine.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael is 43 years old and widowed with two children.  As the breadwinner in her family, she is able to raise her children with the income from her business where she sells second-hand clothes.  She has been operating the business for thirteen years and has managed to employ one person.  Her desire is to supply clothing wholesale in the future.  She has requested 50,000 Kes to buy shirts.

loans.use: To buy shirts

loans.name: Meylin Auxiliadora

texts.es: Meylin Auxiliadora tiene 41 años, su actividad es brindar el servicio de bar y comedor. Hace más de 17 años que tiene este negocio. Es una mujer muy emprendedora y disfruta de este medio de vida. Tiene 3 hijos,  que los mantuvo con el gran esfuerzo de trabajo a pesar de ser una actividad muy humilde ha logrado obtener lo necesario. El motivo del financiamiento es para la compra de granos básicos, verduras, platos desechables, frutas para la elaboración de refrescos naturales. Espera en un futuro llegar en transformar su pequeño bar y comedor en un restaurante.
texts.en:
Meylin Auxiliadora, 41, has an eatery/bar.  She’s been in business for over 17 years.  She is a very enterprising woman who enjoys this way of life.

She has three children that she supported thanks to the great effort she put into work. Despite its being a very humble activity it has provided everything necessary.

The reason for the financing is to buy basic grains, vegetables, disposable plates and fruit to make natural beverages.  She hopes in the future to transform her small eatery/bar into a restaurant.

loans.use: To buy basic grains, vegetables, disposable plates and fruit.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more tools for his business

loans.name: Ganzorig

texts.en:
Ganzorig is 45 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arhangai province of Mongolia in his own house and fence. His youngest two children attend a local secondary school while the oldest son and wife help with his business. 

Ganzorig started a raw materials trading business in 2003 and ran it for several years. In 2009 he changed his trading business into a carpentry business, which has more demand and brings more profit. He produces ger wooden parts, such as wooden doors, floors, and walls and delivers them to his customers with his own truck. (A "ger" is a traditional Mongolian house tent.) 

Ganzorig is an honest and hardworking businessman. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more materials for his carpentry business.
